perturbation.changed_text:
Pursuant to and for the purposes of the Privacy Code and EU Reg. 679/2016 ("GDPR") ("Law") on "Protection of persons and other subjects with regard to the processing of personal data", the Parties - as autonomous Data Controllers - acknowledge that they may at times exchange information on the use of personal data.

The Parties can communicate to each other - in execution of this Contract - common and/or sensitive personal data of third parties whether they have been given prior information and acquired consent or not.
perturbation.explanation: This change significantly weakens the GDPR compliance by suggesting the exchange of personal data is optional ('may at times') and removing the explicit requirement for prior informed consent. The added clause 'whether they have been given prior information and acquired consent or not' introduces a legal contradiction by directly opposing GDPR's core tenet of requiring consent for processing personal data. This relocation severely undermines the enforceability of GDPR within this contract.

perturbation.original_text: All disputes arising out of or in connection with this Agreement shall be finally settled under the Rules of Arbitration of the International Chamber of Commerce by one or more arbitrators appointed in accordance with the said Rules. Any such arbitration shall (i) be subject to the application of the Italian Law, (ii) take place in Paris, France and (iii) be conducted in English.
perturbation.changed_text: All disputes arising out of or in connection with this Agreement may be settled by a method agreed upon by both parties, including but not limited to, mediation, litigation, or other alternative dispute resolution methods. If arbitration is chosen, it will be conducted under mutually agreed upon rules.
perturbation.explanation: The original clause mandated ICC arbitration, but the modified clause introduces a contradiction by allowing parties to choose any dispute resolution method, making arbitration optional and its rules subject to mutual agreement. This weakens the enforceability of the arbitration clause by removing its mandatory nature and predetermined framework.
